Award.AwardTitle: CNS: Collaborative Research: EAGER: From Computer Networks to Food Networks

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

Award.AbstractNarration:
With food sourced from every part of the country and from around the world, food supply chains are extremely complex pathways from farm to the table. Unfortunately, up to 20-30% of the fresh food is spoiled by the time it reaches the customer in US, and a similar amount is further thrown away by the customers at least partly due to lack of freshness. Thus, understanding food networks and devising mechanisms to reduce losses can have huge economic and environmental impact. The purpose of this project is to understand and improve food distribution networks by applying and extending techniques from the science of computer networking, which can handle tremendous amounts of complexity beyond the scales seen in food networks. The unique characteristics of food networks will require significant innovations beyond the state of the art in computer networking and thus will provide valuable results for novel and emerging complex computer networks as well.

The design and optimization of a "food network" poses many challenges and requires innovations that are expected to benefit both food networks and computer networks. In particular, food network involve unique 'rotting packets' (continuous decrease in quality of the package contents), a demand-driven and quality-centric delivery and distribution, in-network bundling/unbundling of 'packets', mixing of a large variety of 'payloads', and dynamic changes to packet sources and types. The purpose of this proposal is to address these challenges and lay the foundation for a systematic design and operation of food networks. Since many of these challenges are relevant to computer networks as well, the proposed work will consider them in that context as well. In particular, the research will examine issues relating to in-network bundling/unbundling of packets, content based (rather than address based) routing/distribution, QoS aware forwarding of multi-modal data, and disruption tolerant operation. The research will also allow for better management of the food networks in the face of emerging trends in maximal utilization of seasonal and local foods which requires significant flexibility and dynamic configurability in the food sourcing and distribution networks.

POR.DRECONTENT:
With food sourced from every part of the country and from around the world, food supply chains are extremely complex pathways from farm to the table. Unfortunately, up to 20-30% of the fresh food is spoiled by the time it reaches the customer in US, and a similar amount is further thrown away by the customers at least partly due to lack of freshness. Thus, understanding food networks and devising mechanisms to reduce losses can have huge economic and environmental impact. The purpose of this project is to understand and improve food distribution networks by applying and extending techniques from computer networking. The complexity and unique characteristics of food networks will require significant innovations beyond the state of the art in computer networking and thus will provide valuable results for emerging complex computer networks as well.

 

Most fresh food originates at the farm and passes through multiple stages that may involve processing, storage, packaging, re-packaging, and transportation before reaching the retail stores. The design and optimization of such a “food network” poses many challenges and requires innovations that are expected to benefit both food networks and computer networks. In particular, food network involve unique “rotting packets” (continuous decrease in quality of the package contents), a demand-driven and quality-centric delivery and distribution, in-network bundling/unbundling of “packets”, mixing of a large variety of “payload”, and dynamic changes to packet sources and types. The purpose of this proposal is to address these challenges and lay the foundation for a systematic design and operation of food networks. Since many of these challenges are relevant to computer networks as well, the proposed work will consider them in that context as well. In particular, the research will examine issues relating to in-network bundling/unbundling of packets, content based (rather than address based) routing/distribution, QoS aware forwarding of multi-modal data, and disruption tolerant operation. The research will also allow for better management of the food networks in the face of emerging trends in maximal utilization of seasonal and local foods which requires significant flexibility and dynamic configurability in the food sourcing and distribution networks. The research will also make significant contributions to the state of the art in computer networks.  

 

We looked into the synergies between Fresh Food Networks (FFNs) and Computer Networks to study them synonymously. One of the key characteristics of FFNs is to monitor freshness or quality of food package based on the delay in the distribution pipeline and handling factors such as temperature, humidity, vibrations, etc. Similarly, while delivering video, we can monitor freshness of a video packet by checking delay in distribution network and handling factors such as bandwidth, availability, interference and so on. A rotten food package that does not reach the end user can be seen analogous to a video packet which was lost in transmission. However, we have to note that while packets of food deteriorate in quality over time, a video packet that is to be delivered can either be delivered intact and on time, or lost in transmission. We further investigated the handling of rotting packets in terms of routing and distribution which forms an interesting study of computer networks, in the light of food networks. We describe a metric for estimating the quality degradation of a food product using its time-temperature indicator.
